ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned a lot about Dionysos, not only in the past but how his legacy has carried into the modern world. It was a fantastic way to broaden my knowledge of ancient art and readings.
Ancient greek forms of thought and art relating to Dionysus. Different forms of Dionysian characteristics and expressions, how to evaluate them and how to interpret them.
I learned how to analyze ancient art and the critical issues of interpretation, categorization, and historical analysis.
I learned about Dionysus and his presence as a very dynamic, complex god, and his place in Greek mythology.
We studied a large swath of Dionysiac art in Ancient Greece, and a bit beyond, including connections to other ancient civilizations and some modern art.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Professor Gaifman was incredible and very accommodating during this difficult time. The material was great, and the group "activities" were always a fun way to engage with what we were reading or looking at.

Strengths:
- comfortable working environment
- easy to communicate with professor and classmates

Weaknesses:
- none. This class is perfect :)
The discussions are group activities were really engaging and worked well

I think the only way it could be improved would have been if we could have gone to the museums and galleries in person and actually seen the artwork at places like the YUAG, which of course was impossible because of covid. Professor Gaifman made sure the course was the best it could have possibly been without the in-person element.

The professor, Millette Gaifman, is amazing. I would absolutely recommend students interested in Greek art take any class she teaches, she is fantastic. Additionally, the organization of this course with both grad students and undergraduates was incredibly helpful for getting contact with upper level scholars and connecting to potential mentors. Beyond the people, the course itself is fantastic. The work and readings are very manageable while also being super engaging. Definitely central to anyone interested in Dionysus, but also he's the best so really everyone should be interested.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: It was all very successful given the circumstances. We were all pretty comfortable talking in the zoom rooms, if at times there could be lulls. But that is to be expected in any zoom class.
Organized publications on canvas, breakout rooms and group activities, motivation for participation, creation of comfortable zoom environment.
Professor Gaifman made this course incredibly engaging, even over zoom. She made it the absolute best it could have been in covid times!

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Absolutely. Hands down it was my favourite class of the semester. Not only is Dionysos a fascinating god to study, the material is varied so there is really something for everyone to enjoy. I would recommend this to anyone and everyone with an interest in antiquity!

I would highly recommend this course, especially with Prof. Gaifman. Learning about Dionysus and the intricacies of what he represents was made fun through an interactive discussion, creation of our own art in groups, presentations of individual group discussions, and a great space to talk about the absurdities of the god of paradox.
Absolutely. Professor Gaifman is an incredible educator who cares deeply about the subject of the class and her students.
I would definitely recommend this course to another student, especially anyone interested in Greek mythology. Professor Gaifman is fantastic and the course is fun and engaging!
YES. Its a very fascinating subject matter and a very well run class.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
